description.short: Measures vulnerability to unconscious archetypal patterns that bypass security protocols when triggered by symbolic messaging
description.context: Archetypes are universal psychological patterns inherited in the collective unconscious that automatically evoke powerful emotional and behavioral responses. When attackers use archetypal themes‚Äî'be the hero,' 'urgent authority request,' 'clever workaround'‚Äîthey trigger pre-cognitive responses that override rational security thinking. Digital environments, being transitional spaces between reality and imagination, create ideal conditions for archetypal projection and activation.
description.impact: Organizations with high archetypal vulnerability experience successful social engineering attacks exploiting emotional themes rather than technical weaknesses. Employees bypass security procedures during 'emergencies' (hero archetype), comply without verification to 'authority figures' (parent archetype), or celebrate 'clever' security violations (trickster archetype). Otherwise security-conscious employees act impulsively when archetypal patterns activate.
description.psychological_basis: Jung's (1969) analytical psychology demonstrates archetypes as universal patterns bypassing ego defenses. fMRI studies show limbic system activation (emotion/instinct) preceding prefrontal cortex (rational analysis) by 300-500ms (LeDoux, 2000). System 1 processing dominates archetypal responses, creating compelling urges to act before conscious security awareness intervenes (Kahneman, 2011).

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 √ó Quick_Assessment + w2 √ó Conversation_Depth + w3 √ó Red_Flags) √ó Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Formal verification procedures consistently followed regardless of emotional appeals. Documented processes require multiple approvals for security exceptions. Incident reports show technical failures rather than psychological manipulation. Regular training addresses emotional manipulation tactics. No authentication bypasses due to urgency in past 90 days.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Some emergency override procedures exist but lack consistent enforcement. Authority-based exceptions occur monthly but are eventually verified. Hero behavior sometimes rewarded despite security violations. Clever workarounds tolerated in low-risk situations. Mixed success resisting archetypal manipulation.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Frequent emergency overrides with minimal verification. Authority figures easily bypass security through status alone. Individual heroics celebrated over process compliance. Clever rule-breaking culturally rewarded. Trust-based decisions common with minimal verification. Archetypal themes dominate security incident patterns.

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Emergency Override Frequency
items.question: How often do employees bypass normal security verification procedures during 'emergency' or 'urgent' situations in a typical month?

options.label: Rarely - Emergency procedures exist but require documented justification and post-incident review, <2 per month
Occasionally - Emergency overrides occur 3-10 times per month with some controls but inconsistent enforcement
Frequently - Emergency overrides common (>10 per month) with minimal verification or review

items.evidence_required: Specific example of most recent emergency override incident
items.soc_mapping: Emergency access request frequency from PAM logs

items.title: Authority Exception Process
items.question: What happens when someone claiming to be a senior executive or external authority requests employees to break normal security procedures?

options.label: Formal verification required through independent channels regardless of claimed authority level
Exceptions granted to authority figures but with senior approval and eventual verification
Authority figures can easily bypass security through status alone with minimal verification

items.evidence_required: Recent example of authority-based request that bypassed standard protocols
items.soc_mapping: Exception requests correlated with authority indicators

items.title: Hero Behavior Response
items.question: When technical issues arise, how often do individual employees take initiative to 'save the day' by working around security controls rather than following established procedures?

options.label: Process compliance rewarded - employees follow procedures and are recognized for proper escalation
Mixed - sometimes hero behavior tolerated in crisis situations but generally discouraged
Individual heroics celebrated - employees who 'save the day' by circumventing controls are rewarded

items.evidence_required: Specific incident where someone tried to be helpful by circumventing security
items.soc_mapping: Security policy override patterns during crisis periods

items.title: Clever Solution Culture
items.question: How does your organization respond when employees find creative technical workarounds that bypass security controls but solve business problems faster?

options.label: Formal review process - clever ideas tested safely before production, security maintained
Tolerated in low-risk situations - clever workarounds sometimes accepted without full review
Cleverness rewarded - creative rule-breaking celebrated despite violating security policies

items.evidence_required: Time when a 'clever hack' was celebrated despite violating security policies

items.title: Trust-Based Decision Patterns
items.question: What verification steps do employees follow when someone presents themselves as trustworthy, helpful, or 'just trying to solve a simple problem'?

options.label: Trust but verify - documented verification procedures regardless of personal trust feelings
Situational - verification performed for high-risk requests but relaxed for 'helpful' interactions
Trust-based - helpful demeanor or simple explanations lead to relaxed security verification

items.evidence_required: Example when someone's helpful demeanor led to relaxed security verification
items.soc_mapping: Verification compliance rates in different interaction contexts

items.title: Archetypal Communication Detection
items.question: When reviewing security requests and incident communications, how often do you notice language like 'emergency,' 'save,' 'authorized by,' 'clever solution,' or 'trust me'?

options.label: Rare - Communications focus on technical details and formal procedures, <10% contain archetypal language
Moderate - 10-40% of security communications contain archetypal language patterns
Frequent - Over 40% of security communications heavily feature archetypal themes and emotional appeals

items.evidence_required: Specific quotes from recent incident reports showing archetypal language patterns
items.soc_mapping: Linguistic pattern analysis of security communications

items.title: Incident Report Archetypal Analysis
items.question: Review your last 10 security incident reports. How many involved attackers using archetypal themes to manipulate employees (hero narratives, authority claims, clever tricks, trust appeals)?

options.label: Minimal - 0-2 incidents involved clear archetypal manipulation themes
Moderate - 3-6 incidents showed archetypal manipulation patterns
Predominant - 7+ incidents clearly involved archetypal theme exploitation

items.evidence_required: Incident report excerpts showing archetypal manipulation attempts
items.soc_mapping: Incident classification by attack vector including psychological themes

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Document specific examples for evidence trail.

items.text: Tell me about the most recent time someone bypassed security procedures because of an 'emergency' situation. What was the emergency, who was involved, and what security steps were skipped?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare occurrence with documented emergency protocols, post-incident review, and corrective actions
scoring_guidance.yellow: Occasional emergencies with some controls but inconsistent application depending on perceived urgency
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent emergency overrides with minimal verification, 'emergency' regularly used to bypass security

followups.text: When employees are asked to help 'save the company' or 'prevent a disaster,' how often do they question whether normal security procedures still apply?
Looking back, how many of these 'emergencies' actually required bypassing security versus being manageable within normal procedures?

items.text: Describe a specific time when a senior executive or claimed authority figure requested something that would normally violate security policy. How did employees respond?

scoring_guidance.green: Verification procedures followed regardless of authority level, documented approval process
scoring_guidance.yellow: Authority status influenced response speed but eventual verification occurred
scoring_guidance.red: Authority figures bypass security based on status alone, employees comply immediately without verification

followups.text: How comfortable are employees questioning or verifying requests from executives or people claiming official authority?
Has anyone ever been criticized or disciplined for following security procedures when an authority figure wanted to bypass them?

items.text: Tell me about a time when an employee worked around security controls to solve a problem or help someone. What happened and how did the organization respond?

scoring_guidance.green: Process compliance rewarded, workarounds addressed through proper channels and security maintained
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed response - workarounds sometimes tolerated depending on outcome and perceived necessity
scoring_guidance.red: Hero behavior celebrated, employees who 'saved the day' by bypassing security are recognized and rewarded

followups.text: Are there stories in your organization about people who 'saved the day' by finding creative solutions? Do those stories involve bypassing security?
How does your organization balance rewarding initiative versus maintaining security procedures?

items.text: When employees discover 'clever' technical workarounds that bypass security controls but make work easier, what typically happens?

scoring_guidance.green: Formal review process channels innovation safely, security maintained while considering improvements
scoring_guidance.yellow: Workarounds tolerated in perceived low-risk situations without full security review
scoring_guidance.red: Technical cleverness rewarded regardless of security impact, 'hacks' spread informally across organization

followups.text: Can you give me an example of a 'clever solution' that was celebrated but actually created security vulnerabilities?
How does your technical culture view security controls - as challenges to overcome or protections to maintain?

items.text: Walk me through a recent security incident involving social engineering. What language did the attacker use, and what convinced the employee to comply?

scoring_guidance.green: Employees recognized and reported manipulation attempts, verification procedures prevented compromise
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some employees susceptible to emotional appeals, mixed success rate in resisting manipulation
scoring_guidance.red: Clear pattern of archetypal language (emergency, authority, help) successfully bypassing security awareness

followups.text: Looking at your recent security incidents, what themes keep appearing - urgency/emergency, authority claims, requests for help, appeals to cleverness?
When you debrief employees after they fall for social engineering, what do they say convinced them - the technical details or the emotional framing?

solutions.title: Verification Pause Protocol
solutions.description: Implement mandatory 60-second pause and second-person verification for any request using emotional language
solutions.implementation: Create decision tree for common scenarios requiring verification. Include automated delay in critical systems for any override attempts. Train recognition of 'urgent,' 'emergency,' 'help,' and 'authorized' trigger words.
solutions.technical_controls: System delays on emergency access, multi-party approval requirements, automated linguistic analysis

solutions.title: Authority Verification Matrix
solutions.description: Establish clear verification procedures for all authority-based requests
solutions.implementation: Callback verification using independently sourced contact information. Two-factor confirmation for security exceptions. Train staff that real executives support security verification procedures.
solutions.technical_controls: Authority validation checklist, callback verification database, approval workflow system

solutions.title: Hero Channel Program
solutions.description: Create legitimate channels for employees to 'save the day' through proper security reporting
solutions.implementation: Publicly recognize employees following security procedures during high-pressure situations. Establish 'Security Hero of the Month' program rewarding process compliance over individual heroics.
solutions.technical_controls: Recognition platform, incident reporting tracking, metrics dashboard

solutions.title: Clever Solution Review Process
solutions.description: Implement formal review for creative technical solutions impacting security
solutions.implementation: Create innovation sandbox where clever ideas tested safely before production. Establish 'Secure Innovation' guidelines celebrating cleverness while maintaining controls.
solutions.technical_controls: Sandbox environment, innovation review board, security testing framework

solutions.title: Trust Verification Training
solutions.description: Deploy scenario-based training focused on verification procedures regardless of trust feelings
solutions.implementation: Create simple 'Trust but Verify' checklist for common social engineering scenarios. Include monthly simulation exercises using trust-based manipulation techniques. Emphasize that verification shows respect, not distrust.
solutions.technical_controls: Training platform with scenarios, simulation engine, progress tracking

solutions.title: Language Pattern Detection
solutions.description: Implement automated monitoring of internal communications for archetypal trigger language
solutions.implementation: Create alert system for security team when emergency/authority/hero language appears in unusual contexts. Develop response protocols for each identified pattern type. Privacy-preserving aggregate analysis only.
solutions.technical_controls: NLP linguistic analysis, pattern detection algorithms, alert dashboard

risk_scenarios.title: Executive Impersonation Attack (Authority Archetype)
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker poses as CEO requiring urgent wire transfer to 'save a deal,' bypassing normal financial controls through authority archetypal activation
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Email or voice impersonation using authority language and urgency markers
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Authority archetype triggers automatic compliance, hero archetype motivates helping company
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Numerous CEO fraud cases where employees felt compelled to help save deals

risk_scenarios.title: IT Hero Manipulation (Hero/Trickster Archetypes)
risk_scenarios.description: Social engineer presents as external consultant who can 'save' company from cyber attack by providing 'emergency' security patches
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Technical authority combined with hero narrative and clever solution framing
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Hero archetype activation makes IT staff install malware while believing they're protecting organization
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Supply chain attacks leveraging trust in 'helpful' security vendors

risk_scenarios.title: Helpful Insider Attack (Innocent Archetype)
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker gains physical access by appearing helpless and trustworthy, activating innocent/nurturing archetypes
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering leveraging help-seeking behavior and trust appeals
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Innocent archetype reduces vigilance, employees 'help' by providing access without verification
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Numerous physical security bypasses using helpless personas

risk_scenarios.title: Technical Wizard Social Engineering (Trickster Archetype)
risk_scenarios.description: Sophisticated attacker demonstrates technical knowledge and presents 'clever' solutions requiring security control bypasses
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Technical competence display combined with creative solution framing
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Trickster/magician archetype activation makes technical staff admire cleverness and implement backdoors
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Advanced persistent threats using technical rapport building
